posts.name: Erik
posts.cooked:
I’m a mentor of team 9578 and I’m hoping that someone out there can help us out because we have been banging our heads against the wall for a couple weeks now.  We are using the new ThriftyBot Swerve modules with the Thrifty absolute encoders on our robot this year.  Getting the modules up and running using YAGSL was much easier than we anticipated, and we had high hopes of a smooth build season.

The first issue we ran into was getting the absolute encoder data from each module to get the offests.  For some reason when we look at the network tables in the Smart Dashboard it only gives us the raw absolute encoder value for our 3rd module.  The others do not show up.  We do see module data in the “Module States” area in the tables but these do not coincide with the absolute encoder data.  We needed to plug each encoder into the #2 rio Analog input to get the data, but we were able to get the offests eventually.  If anyone knows how we can do this easier next year it would be greatly appreciated.

Second we seem to be having an issue getting data from our 4th swerve module.  When we look at the “Module States” information in the network tables on robot connection, we see the first three modules giving a different angle reading (the decimal values jumping around), but the fourth module is always a solid zero with no decimal movement.  When we physically turn the module it starts counting (I’m assuming due to the relative encoder).  It almost seems like it isn’t pulling the absolute encoder data.  We switched out 3 different encoders, we changed the data wire running to the Rio, we even swapped in a different Rio thinking it was a bad analog port.  However, when we plug this encoder into port 2 (the one that shows raw absolute encoder data on the network tables) the encoder values change when we rotate the module.  When we try to give this module an offset it has no effect.  The only way we can drive our robot is to align this one wheel with our jig before we power on the robot so it is facing forward before it gets power.

Please help if you can!  We are hoping to get this drive based wrapped up this weekend so we can start attaching the other parts of our robot.

We have our program published to a gitlab, so hopefully you have access to it if you need to see it.

2025 9578_PlayerOne SwerveProgram

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked:
tieted06:

We needed to plug each encoder into the #2 rio Analog input to get the data, but we were able to get the offests eventually. If anyone knows how we can do this easier next year it would be greatly appreciated.

All 4 encoders don’t need to port #2 . It should be 1 for each. Ex. Front Right Encoder goes to Analog port #0 Back Right Encoder goes to Analog port #1 Back Left Encoder goes to Analog port #2 Front Left Encoder goes to Analog port #3

Also make sure your magnet placement is set properly image 998×866 74 KB

image 998×866 74 KB

image 998×866 74 KB
Can you send a photo of your encoder cables to your roboRIO and encoder

posts.name: Erik
posts.cooked: Sorry if I wasn’t clear.  We only used Port 2 on the Rio to get the offsets of each module.  Port 2 is the only raw absolute encoder value being displayed in our SmartDashboard.  Once we have the offsets entered for each module we use all 4 analog inputs (one for each module) again.  We can technically drive our robot around, but this seemed like it wasn’t the most efficient way to get our offests in the first place.

posts.name: Erik
posts.cooked: I wish I could but I won’t see the robot again until tomorrow.  I probably wasn’t as clear as I could have been, but we do have each module going to it’s own analog port on the rio.  Modules going to the 0, 1, and 2 ports on the Rio function as expected.  The module (back right module) going to port 3 is the one we are having difficulty with.

posts.name: Erik
posts.cooked:
@nstrike Here are the photos you requested.  The wire management of our robot is non-existent at the moment

IMG_1318 1920×2560 568 KB

IMG_1318 1920×2560 568 KB

IMG_1318 1920×2560 568 KB

I wasn’t sure if this was a hardware issue, a software issue, or maybe a bit of both.  I just did an experiment where I swapped the CAN ID’s and encoder ID’s in the config Json files of my front left module (which is working fine) and the back right module (which doesn’t seem like it’s sending absolute encoder data).  After I power cycled the robot the issue was no longer with the original rear right module.  The problem migrated to whichever module I designated as the rear right module.

One of the values on the SmartDashboard should be the Module State angle of the Rear Right Module.  No matter which way the wheel starts at it will always show zero.

After I swapped the info of the left front and rear right config Json files.  The SmartDashboard is still zero for the last module, and now my front left module won’t initialize to a zero position at startup. From what I can see it seems to me that the encoder is sending data through the analog port on the Rio, but for some reason the YAGSL library isn’t sending it through, but only for the Rear Right module.

posts.name: Erik
posts.cooked:
On my way home I got to thinking, “Why would only one of the modules not be getting the encoder data?  All the modules are set up the same.”  I then had a sneaking suspicion.  I took a look at the RightRear config file my team made a few weeks ago and the answer was staring me in the face.

“encoder”: { “type”: “none”, “id”:  3; “canbus”: null

I actually facepalmed myself on this one.  I guess it will be a good learning experience for the team, at any rate.  I’ll post an update tomorrow during our meeting to see if this is the problem.
